properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 10 to 15 cm of snow is forecast for Saturday as a low pressure system moves across the area. The moist airmass will interact with the cooler lower atmosphere to generate lower density snow of 10 to 15 cm. The snow will end Saturday overnight as the low moves out of the region. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-05T15:14:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-04T23:15:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0950407408.2020
Area: Whitehorse
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected. Total snowfall: 30 cm or more. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h or more. Locations: Eagle River and Norman Bay to Lodge Bay. Time span: Sunday afternoon until Monday night. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Sunday afternoon, and become heavy, at times, on Sunday night into Monday. Strong northeasterly winds in conjunction with the fresh snowfall will result in poor visibility in blowing snow. Conditions will improve on Tuesday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-06T01:08:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-05T09:09:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3379885642.2020
Area: Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intense low pressure system will move across the province of Quebec this weekend. This storm will bring significant snow, strong winds, blowing snow and a risk of freezing rain over several areas of Eastern Quebec Sunday. Meanwhile, snowfall warnings associated with this system have already been issued over the eastern portion of the Eastern Townships and over higher grounds of the Chaudière-Appalaches region where near 25 cm of snow are expected from Saturday evening to Sunday. Similar amounts are possible over the Lower St Lawrence, the Gaspé Peninsula and the Lower North Shore Sunday. These poor weather conditions may have a significant impact on travel. Be prepared for changing road conditions that could deteriorate rapidly in heavy snow and blowing snow. Future weather statements will provide more details as the low pressure system's track as well as precipitation types and amounts become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-05T19:17:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-05T03:18:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3181598192.2020
Area: Mont-Joli area, Le Bic - Rimouski area, Rimouski Wildlife Reserve area, Matane, Amqui area, Matapédia area, Grande-Vallée area, Sainte-Anne-des-Monts area, Murdochville area, Mont-Albert area, Grande-Rivière - Cascapédia area, New-Richmond - Bonaventure area, Restigouche - Carleton area, Chandler area, New Carlisle - Port-Daniel area, Forillon National Park - Gaspé area, Percé area, Natashquan, Chevery, Blanc-Sablon, Anticosti, Montmagny - Saint-Jean-Port-Joli area, Trois-Pistoles area, Pohénégamook area, Kamouraska area, Rivière-du-Loup area, Témiscouata

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system will track across Southeastern Quebec Sunday and Monday. As this system approaches, snowfall amounts of 15 to 20 cm are expected Saturday evening into Sunday morning over the eastern part of the Eastern Townships and over higher grounds of the Chaudiere-Appalaches region. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-06T00:45:11-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Amounts of 2 to 5 millimetres of freezing precipitation are expected over these areas Sunday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall of 5 to 10 cm expected tonight and a further 20 cm on Saturday. A series of Pacific frontal systems will move across the region over the next few days and give periods of snow, at times heavy. Snowfall accumulation of near 20 cm are expected for each 24 hour period that began early on Friday and will continue through the weekend. The heavy snow will ease early next week. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-05T16:44:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-05T00:45:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1911769842.2020
Area: South Klondike Highway - Carcross to White Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall amounts near 50 mm are expected. A slow moving front over the north coast is bringing rain to Stewart and Kitimat. Rain will taper off overnight in Kitimat as the front moves northward but will begin in Stewart this evening. Rain will persist most of Saturday in Stewart. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-05T16:09:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-05T00:10:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3930047843.2020
Area: North Coast - inland including Kitimat, North Coast - inland including Stewart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intense low pressure system will develop over the Eastern U.S. Seaboard on Saturday. It will affect Central Quebec beginning Saturday evening, then reach Eastern Quebec on Sunday. This storm may bring significant snowfall amounts, strong winds, widespread blowing snow, and even freezing rain. Although it is still too early to forecast with certainty how much snow will fall and what areas will be hardest hit, the Lower St. Lawrence and the Gaspé Peninsula could see up to 30 centimetres of snow. Freezing rain should mainly affect the Eastern Gaspé Peninsula. These poor weather conditions may have a significant impact on travel. Be prepared for changing road conditions that could deteriorate rapidly in heavy snow and blowing snow. Future weather statements will provide more details as the low pressure system's track as well as precipitation types and amounts become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-05T09:55:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-04T17:56:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0498562186.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall amounts of 15 to 30 centimetres, strong winds and blowing snow are expected. An intense low pressure system will affect Eastern Quebec and bring snow at times heavy Saturday evening and Sunday over the Lower St. Lawrence and the Gaspé Peninsula areas. This storm will also be accompanied by strong winds gusting up to 80 km/h. These winds combined with snow will reduce visibilities to near zero over these regions beginning overnight tonight or Sunday morning. There is also a risk of freezing rain over the Eastern Gaspé Peninsula. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-06T01:04:43-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall Sunday night to Monday night. Locations: Upper Lake Melville area and Cartwright to Black Tickle. Total snowfall: 15 cm or more. Remarks: Cartwright to Black Tickle will see snow develop on Sunday night becoming heavy, at times on Monday. Strong northerly winds will reduce the visibility in blowing snow. A winter storm watch may be issued with subsequent forecasts. Depending on the track of the low, the Upper Lake Melville area may or may not see significant snowfall. Confidence for this area is lower. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Summary:

Reduced visibilities in blowing snow are possible over exposed areas. Conditions will improve on Monday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. properties.Title: Les Suêtes Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum Les Suetes gusts: 90 km/h. Time span: Overnight Saturday until early Sunday morning. Remarks: Strong southeast winds will develop Saturday evening with gusts to 90 km/h overnight until early Sunday morning. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Les Suêtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Total rainfall: 25 to 45 mm. Locations: Yarmouth and Digby counties. Time span: beginning this morning and tapering off to showers near midnight tonight. Remarks: Rainfall amounts may be lower than the standard criteria for a rainfall warning; however, the saturated ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Significant pooling and runoff are likely to occur. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall Sunday night to Monday night. Locations: Eagle River, Cartwright to Black Tickle, Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair. Maximum snowfall: Possibly exceeding 30 cm, especially inland. Remarks: Areas immediately along the coast from L'Anse-au-Clair to Mary's Harbour may see precipitation fall as rain or wet snow, significantly reducing accumulations. If precipitation falls only as rain, accumulations could reach 30 mm instead. Location: Upper Lake Melville. Maximum snowfall: Possibly reaching 15 cm. Remarks: Depending on the track of the low, the Upper Lake Melville area may or may not see significant snowfall. Confidence for this area is lower. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Strong winds, with gusts up to 80 km/h, will maintain blizzard conditions tonight. These blizzard conditions will end overnight as the wind starts to weaken. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, rain and wind is expected this evening into Sunday. Total snowfall: possibly exceeding 20 cm. Total rainfall: 15 to 25 mm. Locations: central and northeastern New Brunswick. Time span: this evening through Monday morning. Remarks: Snow and strong winds are expected to spread across parts of New Brunswick late this afternoon. The snow may change briefly over to ice pellets over central and northeastern parts of the province overnight Saturday before changing over to rain on Sunday morning. Snowfall warnings are currently in effect for northwestern New Brunswick and may be expanded further east or south as the system approaches. Additionally, strong winds are expected to develop tonight and strengthen further on Sunday morning along the Bay de Chaleur and Acadian coasts. A wind warning has been issued for the Acadian Peninsula. Conditions will improve on Monday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-06T00:49:17-00:00
